description: Well-developed eyes adapted to low light conditions, allowing sharks to see clearly in murky waters. relation: Sharks --[Detects Using]-> Ampullae of Lorenzini--description:Sharks use the ampullae of Lorenzini to detect electrical signals from prey.-- name: Olfactory System
type: Sensory Organ
description: A highly developed system that allows sharks to detect minute traces of chemicals in the water, such as blood. relation: Sharks --[Detects Using]-> Tapetum Lucidum--description:Sharks use the tapetum lucidum to enhance their ability to see in low light conditions.-- relation: Sharks --[Preys On]-> Marine Animals--description:Sharks are predators of various marine animals.-- name: Lateral Line System
type: Sensory Organ
description: A system of sensory organs that runs along the length of a shark"s body, helping it detect vibrations and movements in the water. name: Ampullae of Lorenzini
type: Sensory Organ
description: Specialized cells located in the head and snout that can detect electrical signals given off by other organisms. name: Tapetum Lucidum
type: Anatomical Structure
description: A specialized structure behind the retina that enhances low light vision. relation: Sharks --[Detects Using]-> Olfactory System--description:Sharks use their olfactory system to detect prey through smell.-- name: sharks
type: Animal
description: Sharks are a group of elasmobranch fish characterized by a cartilaginous skeleton, five to seven gill slits on the sides of the head, and pectoral fins that are not fused to the head. name: Shark Sensory System
type: Biological System
description: The shark sensory system includes various senses such as smell, hearing, vision, and touch, which work together to make sharks highly efficient predators. name: Great White Shark
type: Animal Species
description: The great white shark is a large predatory shark known for its size and strength. It has several specialized sensory structures that enhance its hunting abilities. name: shark
type: Predator
description: Sharks are large marine predators known for their keen senses and hunting abilities. They use a combination of smell, hearing, electroreception, vision, and touch to detect prey. name: eyes
type: Anatomical Structure
description: The eyes are sensory organs that allow sharks to see, particularly in low light conditions and murky waters. relation: eyes --[Part Of]-> shark--description:The eyes are part of the shark"s sensory system, which includes other senses like smell, hearing, and electroreception.-- relation: eyes --[Used For]-> prey detection--description:The eyes are used by sharks to detect prey, especially in low light conditions.-- relation: eyes --[Enhanced By]-> tapetum lucidum--description:The eyes are enhanced by the presence of the tapetum lucidum, which improves their ability to see in low light.-- name: tapetum lucidum
type: Anatomical Structure
description: The tapetum lucidum is a specialized structure found behind the retinas of some species of sharks, such as the great white shark. It enhances their ability to see in low light conditions. relation: tapetum lucidum --[Found In]-> Great White Shark--description:The tapetum lucidum is found in the eyes of the great white shark, enhancing its vision in low light conditions.-- name: prey detection
type: Behavior
description: Prey detection is a critical behavior for sharks to locate and capture their food. relation: tapetum lucidum --[Enhances]-> Vision--description:The tapetum lucidum enhances the vision of sharks, particularly in low light conditions.-- name: shark
type: Predator
description: Sharks are large marine predators known for their keen senses and hunting abilities. They use a combination of smell, hearing, electroreception, vision, and touch to detect prey. name: Keen Eyesight
type: Sensory Ability
description: Sharks have keen eyesight that helps them detect prey in various conditions.
